flow.context: Chad Rowe is COO of Moving Mountains — 250 luxury vacation rentals across Steamboat Springs, Vail, Beaver Creek, and Breckenridge. They run Breezeway for field ops and Track as their PMS. Just took investment from StayTerra (May 2025) and have been growing through acquisitions (Triumph Mountain Properties, Paragon Lodging). As COO, Chad owns cross-market operational consistency, which is under real pressure from all that growth and integration. They staff dedicated QA inspector roles in every market and promise owners detailed pre-arrival and post-stay inspections. Sam skied Jackson Hole in January — natural connection to a luxury ski-town operator. Strongest technical angle: AI photo analysis layering on top of the Breezeway and Track stack they already use, zero workflow change.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to Chad? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Don't pitch. Don't explain. Say it like you know him. Pause and wait for their response.

branches.label: He's not available / out of office

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah, I work with a few other luxury property managers in the mountain markets. Would you mind letting Chad know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Dose info slowly. Don't pitch the product. Keep it casual — you're a peer, not a vendor. End with the redirect question.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally fair — we help a couple other property management companies with their inspection workflows. I sent Chad a note — would you mind just giving him a heads up that Sam Parks from RapidEye called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Third attempt. If they still won't budge, ask for best time to reach Chad directly and exit gracefully. Don't burn the gatekeeper relationship.

gatekeeper_timing.label: GATEKEEPER — TIMING
gatekeeper_timing.say: No worries at all. When's the best time to catch Chad directly? I want to make sure I'm not bugging you guys again at the wrong time.
gatekeeper_timing.note: Get a specific day and time. Write it down. Be warm — gatekeepers remember how you treated them. If they mention Lisa Riniker or another name, note it for a secondary contact.

branches.label: Gives a time or callback window
Won't share / just says try again

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Chad — I work with a few luxury property managers out in the ski markets. I'm actually a big skier myself, was just out in Jackson Hole last month. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard the name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet up on the desk energy. Not chipper. The skiing line makes you a real person who lives in the same world he does — not a telemarketer. Pause after 'tossed around' and let the silence work.

branches.label: Bad timing / in the middle of something
What is this? / Are you selling something?

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your shoes. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, listen and use it to steer the conversation. If he's vague, that's fine — just transition into the pain trigger naturally.

branches.label: Describes what he heard / asks questions

heard_no.label: HEARD NO
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
heard_no.note: Deliver this lightly, almost laughing at yourself. Then go straight into pain trigger without a long pause. The self-deprecation disarms.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? I'll keep it super quick.
bad_timing.note: Respect it. Don't push. If he gives you a time, lock it in and end clean. If he says 'just tell me now,' he's actually giving you permission.

branches.label: Just tell me now / what's this about?

reschedule_set.label: RESCHEDULE SET
reschedule_set.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Chad. Talk soon.
reschedule_set.note: Write down the exact time. Set a reminder. Call back exactly when you said you would — reliability builds trust before you even pitch.

permission_ask.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_ask.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll own that. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_ask.note: Self-deprecating honesty disarms. You're acknowledging reality — that earns respect from an ops-minded COO. Pause and let him decide.

branches.label: No / not interested / send an email

permission_denied.label: PERMISSION DENIED
permission_denied.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_denied.note: This splits the objection. If it's timing, you get a callback. If it's disinterest, you get a reason you can work with. Either way you learn something.

branches.label: Bad timing / just slammed right now
Opens up slightly / what do you do?

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I've been working with another luxury PM company — pretty similar setup to you guys. About 200 homes, multiple mountain markets, also integrating properties from acquisitions. Their COO told me the hardest part wasn't adding new homes — it was keeping quality consistent across locations. His QA team was snapping hundreds of photos every turnover, but nobody had the bandwidth to actually review them all carefully. Stuff would slip through — a stain on a sofa, a scratch on a dining table, a missing throw blanket — and at their nightly rates, that kind of miss turns into a one-star review and an angry owner call. We built an AI that plugs right into Breezeway and Track — analyzes every photo the team's already taking and auto-flags damage, missing items, staging issues. No workflow change. Would you be open to seeing what that looks like when I'm not catching you off guard?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after 'angry owner call' — let the pain land before you offer the solution. If he reacts mid-story, STOP and let him talk. The Breezeway + Track name-drop shows you did your homework. Don't rush the CTA at the end — let it breathe.

branches.label: Interested / that's relevant / tell me more
We already use Breezeway for that
Not a priority / budget's tight / we're set
That's more of an ops-level thing / someone else handles that

warm_discovery.label: WARM — DISCOVERY
warm_discovery.say: Appreciate that. I don't want to assume anything — what does your inspection process actually look like right now across the four markets? Are your QA teams all running through Breezeway for the photo capture, or is it a mix?
warm_discovery.note: STOP PITCHING. You're in discovery mode. Let him talk. Listen for: how many photos per turnover, what falls through cracks, who reviews photos, how they handle post-acquisition standardization, whether Breezeway is fully adopted or partially. Take notes on everything.

branches.label: Describes current process / shares pain points
Sounds ready / asks about next steps
Defers to someone else on the team

warm_deeper_process.label: WARM — DEEPER ON PROCESS
warm_deeper_process.say: That makes a lot of sense. So when a QA specialist flags something — say they catch damage after a checkout — how does that get to maintenance right now? Is that flowing through Breezeway automatically, or is there a manual handoff in there somewhere?
warm_deeper_process.note: You're mapping their workflow. The goal is to find the bottleneck — where photos pile up, where things get missed, where the handoff to maintenance breaks down. They have separate QA and maintenance teams in every market, so the coordination layer is where pain hides. When you feel the gap is clear, pivot to the CTA.

branches.label: Explains workflow / reveals gaps or manual steps

warm_stayterra_angle.label: WARM — GROWTH AND STAYTERRA ANGLE
warm_stayterra_angle.say: Yeah — I saw you guys brought on StayTerra and have been integrating acquired portfolios over the last couple years. That's exactly the kind of inflection point where the old process starts cracking. When you went from Steamboat's way of doing QA to running it across four markets with different teams, was there a moment where you realized the photo review just wasn't scaling the same way?
warm_stayterra_angle.note: This is a high-value moment. If he opens up about post-acquisition standardization challenges, you're building the business case in his own words. Let him talk. Don't jump to the pitch. If he gets specific about which acquisitions were hardest to integrate, that's gold for the demo.

branches.label: Acknowledges the strain but seems cautious

cta_meeting.label: CTA — ASK FOR MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Look, I don't want to eat up your whole afternoon on a cold call. Would you be open to a quick 15 minutes where I can show you what this actually looks like inside Breezeway and Track? Worst case you see what other luxury operators are doing with their turnover photos and steal some ideas.
cta_meeting.note: Low pressure. 'Worst case you steal some ideas' makes the meeting valuable even if they never buy. If he says yes, immediately lock in a time — don't let it float. If he wants to loop in Lisa Riniker or someone else, even better.

branches.label: Yeah / sure / I'd be open to that
Loop in Lisa or someone else too

book_meeting_with_referral.label: BOOK MEETING — ADD TEAM
book_meeting_with_referral.say: Love it — Lisa Riniker, your Director of Ops, right? Let's get her on too. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up — what works better for you and Lisa?
book_meeting_with_referral.note: Dropping Lisa's name shows homework without being creepy. If he names someone else — Anna Calhoon, Erin Hawthorne, Melissa Caton — use their name instead. Lock in the time NOW while he's warm.

branches.label: Needs to check with them first

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Perfect. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up — how does Tuesday afternoon look? Say 2 PM Mountain time?
book_meeting.note: Pick a specific day and time. Don't say 'when works for you' — that creates friction and delays. Offer two options max. Send the calendar invite while you're still on the phone if possible.

branches.label: Let me check and get back to you

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED
meeting_booked.say: Awesome — I'll shoot over a calendar invite right now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Chad. Enjoy the rest of ski season out there.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. The meeting is booked. Send the invite immediately after you hang up. Be warm, be brief, get off the phone. The ski season closer ties back to the opener and ends on a human note.

objection_have_breezeway.label: OBJECTION — WE USE BREEZEWAY
objection_have_breezeway.say: That's actually ideal — and I know you guys are on Breezeway, that's partly why I called. We're not replacing Breezeway at all. Your QA team is already capturing photos in their workflow — we just add an AI layer on top that actually reviews every single one of those photos and flags what needs attention. Right now, how many of those turnover photos would you say actually get looked at carefully by a human before the guest arrives?
objection_have_breezeway.note: This is the number one objection you'll get because they DO use Breezeway. The reframe is critical: not a replacement, an enhancement. The question at the end exposes the real gap — they're capturing photos but not reviewing them all. Breezeway doesn't do AI damage detection. Let him answer.

branches.label: Admits not all photos get reviewed / sees the gap
Says Breezeway handles it / we're fully covered
Curious / tell me more about the AI layer

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would've reached out to someone like us already. Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that inspection quality honestly isn't something you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate getting cold called?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise him by not pushing back. The split question gives him a face-saving way to keep talking if the real issue is just the cold call format, not the product.

branches.label: It's the cold call / just bad timing
Actually we do have some issues with...

objection_split_interest.label: OBJECTION — SPLIT ON INTEREST
objection_split_interest.say: Totally fair. Out of curiosity — when your team does a turnover on one of the Apex Collection properties, how many photos is the QA specialist taking? And does someone actually review every one of those before the guest walks in?
objection_split_interest.note: You're not arguing — you're asking a question that exposes the gap. Apex Collection is their highest-end tier with daily housekeeping and turndown service. If the answer is 'nobody reviews them all,' you've reopened the conversation naturally.

branches.label: Admits gaps / not every photo gets reviewed
Actually that IS a pain point

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Especially with the StayTerra investment and all the portfolio integration you guys have been working through — I'm sure every dollar's accounted for right now.
objection_no_budget.note: Agree and show you understand their specific situation. The StayTerra reference signals real homework and gives him credit for being in a complex moment. Then move to the split.

branches.label: It's not even about budget, it's timing

objection_split_budget.label: OBJECTION — SPLIT ON BUDGET
objection_split_budget.say: Just so I know — is it that the budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new you try to bring in puts you through the ringer with approvals?
objection_split_budget.note: You're learning whether this is a timing issue or a structural issue. If budget opens next quarter or next fiscal year, sell the test drive now so he's educated when money frees up. If it's approval chains, ask who else would need to be involved.

objection_split_vendor.label: OBJECTION — SPLIT ON VENDOR
objection_split_vendor.say: Makes total sense — with 250 properties across four markets you'd have to have something solid in place. Is it that Breezeway is fully handling the photo review side and you're happy with what it catches, or is it more that adding anything else right now would just be a headache on top of everything else you're integrating?
objection_split_vendor.note: Breezeway doesn't do AI photo analysis — it captures and organizes photos but doesn't auto-detect damage or staging issues. If he says Breezeway 'handles it,' he may not realize there's a gap. If it's change fatigue, sell the zero-workflow-change angle hard.

branches.label: It's more about change fatigue / too much going on
Actually the photo review IS a gap

objection_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
objection_test_drive.say: Totally hear you — and you're probably not buying anything right now, I get that. But when budget does open up or the dust settles on the integrations, the people who move fast are the ones who already know what's first on their list. Would you be open to just seeing it? Fifteen minutes — I can show you what it looks like inside your Breezeway and Track setup specifically. Worst case you see how other luxury operators handle turnover photo review and we part as friends.
objection_test_drive.note: This is your last real swing. You're not asking him to buy — you're asking him to be informed. The specific reference to their Breezeway + Track stack removes 'this won't work with our tools' before it forms. If he still says no, go graceful end or email.

branches.label: Sure / fine / I'll take a look

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over. One quick question so it's not just another generic pitch in your inbox: would it be more useful if I showed you the Breezeway integration side of how it works, or would a before-and-after of what the AI actually catches on real luxury property photos be more relevant?
send_email.note: Don't just say 'sure' and hang up — that email will never get read. The question tailors the email AND re-engages him for one more answer. Whatever he picks, send it within the hour with a specific meeting time suggestion included.

branches.label: Gives a preference / answers the question

send_email_confirm.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED
send_email_confirm.say: Done — I'll get that over today. Is chad@movingmountains.com the best address? And hey, if it's useful after you look at it, I'll follow up Thursday to see if a quick call makes sense. Appreciate your time, Chad.
send_email_confirm.note: Confirm the email — don't assume the pattern is right. Locking in a follow-up day gives you permission to call back without it being another cold call. Send the email within 60 minutes while the conversation is fresh.

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — FIND THE RIGHT PERSON
referral_ask.say: Totally makes sense — I appreciate you telling me that. Who on your team would typically own the inspection workflow and the tooling around it? Would that be more at the Director of Ops level, or is it someone at the market level like your QA managers?
referral_ask.note: You're fishing for a name. If he says Lisa Riniker, great. If he names Anna Calhoon, Erin Hawthorne, Melissa Caton, or someone else from the research, even better — confirm the name and role. Your goal is a name plus permission to use Chad's name when you call them.

branches.label: Says he's actually the right person

referral_get_name.label: REFERRAL — GET THE INTRO
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — would you mind if I reached out to them directly and mentioned we chatted? That way it doesn't come totally out of left field for them. And I can put something together that's actually tailored to what they deal with day-to-day so it's not a random cold pitch.
referral_get_name.note: You want two things: permission to use Chad's name, and a confirmed contact. If he offers to make the intro himself, that's the best outcome — take it. If he just says 'go ahead and call them,' that's still a warm lead.

branches.label: Sure / go ahead and mention me
Just call them directly / gives a number

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL CONFIRMED
referral_confirmed.say: Really appreciate that, Chad. I'll reach out to them this week and keep it relevant. Thanks for your time — enjoy the rest of ski season out there.
referral_confirmed.note: End warm. The ski season line ties back to the opener and ends on a human note. Send the referral outreach within 24 hours while Chad still remembers the call. Mention Chad by name in your opener to that person.

referral_internal.label: REFERRAL — INTERNAL PASS
referral_internal.say: Appreciate that. Would it help if I sent you a quick one-pager you could forward along? I'll keep it tight — just what's relevant to your team's Breezeway and Track setup. That way it's not me cold calling another person on your team out of nowhere.
referral_internal.note: If he wants to pass it along himself, make it effortless. Send a concise one-pager he can forward with one click. Follow up in 3-4 business days to check if it landed.

graceful_end.label: GRACEFUL END
graceful_end.say: Totally understand, Chad. If anything changes, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time — enjoy the rest of the season out there.
graceful_end.note: Don't burn the bridge. Be warm, be brief, get off the phone. Log the call with detailed notes on what he said and why he passed. Set a reminder to try again in 6-8 weeks — especially around seasonal ramp-up before summer or winter peak.
